message.content:
Do deep research to find legitimate scientific studies and sources for facial aesthetics, proportions, and attractiveness. Search for:

1. Published studies on facial proportions and attractiveness (golden ratio, neoclassical canons)
2. Research on facial symmetry and perception
3. Studies on specific features (jaw angle, eye tilt, facial width-to-height ratio)
4. Meta-analyses on facial attractiveness
5. Dermatology and skincare efficacy studies
6. Supplement efficacy studies (collagen, vitamin D, etc.)

Find real DOI links, PubMed references, and peer-reviewed journals. Create a list of at least 20-30 legitimate sources with:
- Title
- Authors
- Journal
- Year
- DOI or PubMed link
- Brief summary of findings

This will be used to update the methodology page with real scientific backing.

facial symmetry attractiveness perception peer-reviewed research DOI
facial width-to-height ratio FWHR attractiveness dominance study pubmed
gonial angle jaw attractiveness orthognathic surgery research study

Links: [{"title":"Judging a man by the width of his face: the role of facial ratios and dominance in mate choice at speed-dating events - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24458269/"},{"title":"Evidence from Meta-Analyses of the Facial Width-to-Height Ratio as an Evolved Cue of Threat - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26181579/"},{"title":"Facial width-to-height ratio predicts self-reported dominance and aggression in males and females, but a measure of masculinity does not - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25339656/"},{"title":"(PDF) Facial Width to Height Ratio and Dominance","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/313797888_Facial_Width_to_Height_Ratio_and_Dominance"},{"title":"Evidence from Meta-Analyses of the Facial Width-to-Height Ratio as an Evolved Cue of Threat - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4504483/"},{"title":"The Role of Facial Ratios and Dominance in Mate Choice ...","url":"https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0956797613511823"},{"title":"Facial Width to Height Ratio and Dominance | SpringerLink","url":"https://link.springer.com/rwe/10.1007/978-3-319-19650-3_1419"},{"title":"Beyond facial width-to-height ratios: bizygomatic width is highly sexually dimorphic when adjusting for allometry | Biology Letters","url":"https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rsbl.2022.0211"},{"title":"Is facial width-to-height ratio reliably associated with social inferences? - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1090513821000568"},{"title":"Was facial width-to-height ratio subject to sexual selection pressures? A life course approach - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7954343/"}]

Here are the search results for facial width-to-height ratio (FWHR), attractiveness, dominance, and related studies from PubMed:

## Key Studies Found:

### 1. Mate Choice and Speed Dating Study
Previous research has shown that men with higher facial width-to-height ratios (fWHRs) have higher testosterone and are more aggressive, more powerful, and more financially successful.(no content)This is the first study to show that male dominance and higher fWHRs are attractive to women for short-term relationships in a controlled and interactive situation that could actually lead to mating and dating.

### 2. Meta-Analysis on FWHR as a Cue of Threat (PubMed/PMC)
Meta-analyses revealed that the FWHR was larger in men than in women (d = .11, n = 10,853), cued judgements of masculinity in men (r = .35), and was related to body mass index (r = .31).(no content)These findings provide some support for the hypothesis that the FWHR is part of an evolved cueing system of intra-sexual threat and dominance in men.(no content)Individuals with larger FWHRs were judged by observers as more threatening than those with smaller FWHRs.(no content)Although studies have reported positive associations between the FWHR and male reproductive success, the meta-analysis found that wider-faced men are judged as less attractive, especially by women, than are narrow-faced men.

### 3. Self-Reported Dominance and Aggression Study
Research shows that: (i) fWHR is related to both self-reported dominance and aggression; (ii) physical aggression, verbal aggression and anger, but not hostility are associated with fWHR; (iii) there is no evidence for a sex difference in associations between fWHR and aggression; and (iv) the facial masculinity index does not predict dominance or aggression.

### 4. Recent Findings on Perceptions
Men with larger fWHRs (i.e. wider faces) are perceived as more masculine, socially dominant and physically aggressive, but not more attractive, than men with smaller fWHRs, suggesting intra-sexual selection as the principle driving force behind sex differences in fWHR.

### 5. Mixed Evidence in Cross-National Research
In preregistered analyses—and exploratory analyses of a subset of traits in a larger sample of 597 faces—researchers found mixed evidence for fWHR-based social judgments.(no content)In exploratory analyses, fWHR was associated positively with perceptions of meanness and aggressiveness in male but not female faces, negatively with attractiveness and dominance in female but not male faces, and negatively with trustworthiness in male but not female faces.

### Summary
The research generally indicates that higher FWHR in men is associated with perceptions of dominance, aggression, and threat, but is typically rated as **less attractive** by women. The relationship appears stronger for intrasexual competition (dominance among males) rather than intersexual selection (female mate choice for attractiveness).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- Biology Insights","url":"https://biologyinsights.com/what-is-the-ideal-gonial-angle-for-men-and-women/"},{"title":"Psychometric and Perceptometric Comparisons of the Perspectives of Orthodontists, Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons, and Laypeople of Different Ages and Sexes towards Beauty of Female Jaw Angles (Intergonial Widths and Gonial Heights) on Frontal and Three‐Quarter Views - Moradinejad - 2022 - BioMed Research International - Wiley Online Library","url":"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1155/2022/2595662"},{"title":"A retrospective analysis of redo orthognathic surgery: Underlying causes, strategy, and outcome - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1010518223000264"},{"title":"Aesthetic Enhancement of the Gonial Angle and Inferior Mandibular Border in the Chinese Population - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10722113/"},{"title":"Survey finds which angles make the perfect jaw | DrBicuspid.com","url":"https://www.drbicuspid.com/dental-specialties/oral-maxillofacial-surgery/article/15544729/survey-finds-which-angles-make-the-perfect-jaw"},{"title":"Psychometric and Perceptometric Comparisons of the Perspectives of Orthodontists, Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons, and Laypeople of Different Ages and Sexes towards Beauty of Female Jaw Angles (Intergonial Widths and Gonial Heights) on Frontal and Three-Quarter Views - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9666021/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what research has found regarding gonial angle, jaw attractiveness, and orthognathic surgery:

## Key Research Findings

### Ideal Female Gonial Angle
If ≥ 80% of participants rated a model as having attractive aesthetic features, it was considered attractive. The following features were considered important: a gonial angle in profile of 125.5° and in anterior view of 142°.(no content)An intergonial-interzygomatic width ratio of 0.83 and the vertical position of the jaw angles at the level of the stomion or upper lip were also identified as important. Surgeons can use these consensus criteria to help design a jaw angle implant, define orthognathic surgical strategies, or shape the angle using injectables.

### Ideal Male Gonial Angle
Research by Mommaerts et al. (2016) found that a mandibular angle of approximately 125.5° and a pronounced posterior contour correlated with optimal male facial aesthetics.(no content)For males, a more acute or "square" angle is often considered aesthetically desirable, typically falling within a range of approximately 120 to 135 degrees. This more defined angle is linked to perceptions of a strong, masculine jawline.

### Professional vs. Layperson Perspectives
Orthodontists and surgeons gave the highest attractiveness scores to intergonial:interzygomatic ratio of 72.53%, while the best ratio was 74.45% for the laypeople. The range of beautiful intergonial:interzygomatic ratio was 72.53% to 86.03%. OMF surgeons and orthodontists gave the highest score to a gonial height of 4.5 mm above the mouth corner, while the laypeople gave the highest score to the gonial height of 4.5 mm below the mouth corner.

### Orthognathic Surgery Considerations
Managing angle definition in patients undergoing orthognathic surgery remains challenging owing to the characteristics of classic mandibular osteotomy, which mostly allows sagittal mandibular movements but cannot modify the ramus height.(no content)The aesthetic result of bimaxillary osteotomy can be disappointing if the angles are not included in the treatment plan, especially in patients with short ramus height or angle asymmetry.

### Cultural Differences
According to the aesthetic standards of the East Asian population, a "square face" is often considered rough and lacking delicacy, lacking the soft beauty that is the mainstream aesthetic preference for an "oval face" or an "egg-shaped face."

### General Principles
The "ideal" gonial angle is not merely a numerical target, but rather a component that integrates with the entire facial structure to achieve an aesthetically pleasing and balanced appearance. Significant natural variation exists among individuals, and perceived attractiveness often stems from the harmonious interplay of all facial features.

Links: [{"title":"The role of the golden proportion in the evaluation of facial esthetics - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23477386/"},{"title":"New “Golden” Ratios for Facial Beauty - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2814183/"},{"title":"Does 3-dimensional facial attractiveness relate to golden ratio, neoclassical canons, ‘ideal’ ratios and ‘ideal’ angles? - PMC","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9452610/"},{"title":"Factors Influencing Perception of Facial Attractiveness: Gender and Dental Education - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29303849/"},{"title":"Beauty Beyond the Golden Ratio: A Study of Perception ...","url":"https://medicaljournal.gazi.edu.tr/index.php/GMJ/article/download/4131/2829/42441"},{"title":"Attractive Versus Golden Ratios: Formula of Utopian Beauty through Comparison of Facial Proportions among Worldwide Celebrities and Average People - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35119402/"},{"title":"Assessment of the golden proportion in natural facial esthetics: A systematic review - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0022391322002852"},{"title":"Does 3-dimensional facial attractiveness relate to golden ratio, neoclassical canons, 'ideal' ratios and 'ideal' angles? - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36070018/"},{"title":"Assessment of the golden proportion in natural facial esthetics: A systematic review - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35738927/"},{"title":"The golden ratio and facial aesthetics","url":"https://jdentalpanacea.org/archive/volume/6/issue/4/article/1295/pdf"}]

Here are the search results on facial attractiveness and the golden ratio from scientific studies:

## Key Research Findings

### Recent Systematic Review (2024)
A systematic review published in the Journal of Prosthetic Dentistry (2024) notes that faces considered attractive tend to possess a general harmony; however, scientific studies on the quantitative basis of human facial attractiveness are still sparse. The golden proportion has been the most documented ratio, but the actual existence of codified facial ratios in facially attractive individuals remains unclear.(no content)The null hypothesis was rejected because the golden proportion was not common in some of the ratios measured. A significant difference from the golden proportion was found in 3 out of 8 measurement ratios, indicating that the golden proportion was not prevalent in the population studied.

### 3D Facial Attractiveness Study (2022)
A study published in Maxillofacial Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery examined the relationship between perception of 3-dimensional facial attractiveness and golden ratio, neoclassical canons, 'ideal' ratios and 'ideal' angles in Hong Kong Chinese.(no content)More than half of the measurements (42/77) in females and thirty-two measurements in males were found to be significantly different from the ideal target value (p < 0.05) upon the comparison of attractive faces with golden ratio, neoclassical canons, 'ideal' ratios and 'ideal' angles.(no content)Despite several renowned 'ideal' parameters of attractive faces that have been recommended in the literature, only a few of them were found to be significantly correlated with attractive faces in Hong Kong Chinese.

### Alternative "New Golden Ratios"
Research from UC San Diego found that individual attractiveness is optimized when the face's vertical distance between the eyes and the mouth is approximately 36% of its length, and the horizontal distance between the eyes is approximately 46% of the face's width. These "new" golden ratios match those of an average face.

### Earlier Research Findings
A study using 3D stereophotogrammetry found that seven out of 10 facial ratios were statistically different from the hypothetical value of 1.618 (the golden ratio), and only three of them were similar to the golden ratio. The conclusions indicated that ratios between 3D facial distances were not related to attractiveness, and most of the facial ratios were different from the golden ratio.

### 2024 Study on Beauty Beyond the Golden Ratio
A 2024 study titled "Beauty Beyond the Golden Ratio" notes that it is accepted that facial proportions with ideal values contribute to facial attractiveness. The "ideal" values for facial proportions are remarkable when assessing the face during perioperative processes, as well as for patients' personal satisfaction. Therefore, defining optimal facial proportions is of significant importance.

The overall scientific consensus from recent research suggests that while the golden ratio (1.618) has historical significance in discussions of beauty, empirical studies generally find that attractive faces often deviate from this classical ratio, and attractiveness may be better predicted by proximity to average facial proportions rather than adherence to the golden ratio.

Here are the peer-reviewed research papers on facial symmetry and attractiveness perception with DOIs:

## Key Peer-Reviewed Studies

### 1. Rhodes et al. (1998) - Foundational Study
"Facial symmetry and the perception of beauty" published in Psychonomic Bulletin & Review 5, 659–669 (1998). https://doi.org/10.3758/BF03208842(no content)This study tested the prediction that facial symmetry is attractive by manipulating the symmetry of individual faces. Attractiveness increased when symmetry was increased, and decreased when symmetry was reduced. Perfectly symmetric versions were preferred to less symmetric versions of the same faces.

### 2. Perrett et al. (1999)
Perrett DI, Burt DM, Penton-Voak IS, Lee KJ, Rowland DA, Edwards R. "Symmetry and human facial attractiveness." Evolution and Human Behavior. 1999 Sept;20(5):295-307. doi: 10.1016/S1090-5138(99)00014-8(no content)This research found that symmetry may act as a marker of phenotypic and genetic quality. When the shape of facial features is varied (with skin textures held constant), increasing symmetry of face shape increases ratings of attractiveness for both male and female faces, implying facial symmetry may have a positive impact on mate selection.

### 3. Simmons et al. (2004)
"Are human preferences for facial symmetry focused on signals of developmental instability?" published in Behavioral Ecology, Volume 15, Issue 5, September 2004, Pages 864–871, https://doi.org/10.1093/beheco/arh099(no content)This study examined why humans find symmetrical faces more attractive. Evolutionary psychologists claim the preference for symmetry can be explained in the context of mate choice because symmetry is an honest indicator of genetic quality. These arguments assume that facial asymmetry is fluctuating asymmetry (FA), revealing developmental instability.

### 4. Rhodes et al. (2011) - Comprehensive Review
"Facial attractiveness: evolutionary based research" published in Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2011 Jun 12;366(1571):1638–1659. doi: 10.1098/rstb.2010.0404(no content)The reasoning for why traits like symmetry are preferred is often related to underlying health. Traits such as symmetry, averageness and secondary sexual characteristics have been proposed to advertise the biological quality of an individual.

### 5. Recent Research (2021)
A 2021 study in Acta Psychologica introduced "facial normality" to explain inconsistencies in previous research on symmetry and attractiveness. The researchers hypothesized that symmetry only increased facial attractiveness when it improved facial normality.(no content)The results demonstrated an interactive effect of symmetry and normality on facial attractiveness, with perceived normality acting as a mediator between symmetry and facial attractiveness.

### 6. Scientific Reports (2019)
Much work has been devoted to assessing the covariation of perceived beauty with facial symmetry, averageness and secondary sexual traits. However, "after decades of intense research, the role played by these traits is known to be limited: facial beauty seems to be more complex than symmetry."

results:
Here are the peer-reviewed research papers on facial symmetry and attractiveness perception with DOIs:

## Key Peer-Reviewed Studies

### 1. Rhodes et al. (1998) - Foundational Study
"Facial symmetry and the perception of beauty" published in Psychonomic Bulletin & Review 5, 659–669 (1998). https://doi.org/10.3758/BF03208842(no content)This study tested the prediction that facial symmetry is attractive by manipulating the symmetry of individual faces. Attractiveness increased when symmetry was increased, and decreased when symmetry was reduced. Perfectly symmetric versions were preferred to less symmetric versions of the same faces.

### 2. Perrett et al. (1999)
Perrett DI, Burt DM, Penton-Voak IS, Lee KJ, Rowland DA, Edwards R. "Symmetry and human facial attractiveness." Evolution and Human Behavior. 1999 Sept;20(5):295-307. doi: 10.1016/S1090-5138(99)00014-8(no content)This research found that symmetry may act as a marker of phenotypic and genetic quality. When the shape of facial features is varied (with skin textures held constant), increasing symmetry of face shape increases ratings of attractiveness for both male and female faces, implying facial symmetry may have a positive impact on mate selection.

### 3. Simmons et al. (2004)
"Are human preferences for facial symmetry focused on signals of developmental instability?" published in Behavioral Ecology, Volume 15, Issue 5, September 2004, Pages 864–871, https://doi.org/10.1093/beheco/arh099(no content)This study examined why humans find symmetrical faces more attractive. Evolutionary psychologists claim the preference for symmetry can be explained in the context of mate choice because symmetry is an honest indicator of genetic quality. These arguments assume that facial asymmetry is fluctuating asymmetry (FA), revealing developmental instability.

### 4. Rhodes et al. (2011) - Comprehensive Review
"Facial attractiveness: evolutionary based research" published in Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2011 Jun 12;366(1571):1638–1659. doi: 10.1098/rstb.2010.0404(no content)The reasoning for why traits like symmetry are preferred is often related to underlying health. Traits such as symmetry, averageness and secondary sexual characteristics have been proposed to advertise the biological quality of an individual.

### 5. Recent Research (2021)
A 2021 study in Acta Psychologica introduced "facial normality" to explain inconsistencies in previous research on symmetry and attractiveness. The researchers hypothesized that symmetry only increased facial attractiveness when it improved facial normality.(no content)The results demonstrated an interactive effect of symmetry and normality on facial attractiveness, with perceived normality acting as a mediator between symmetry and facial attractiveness.

### 6. Scientific Reports (2019)
Much work has been devoted to assessing the covariation of perceived beauty with facial symmetry, averageness and secondary sexual traits. However, "after decades of intense research, the role played by these traits is known to be limited: facial beauty seems to be more complex than symmetry."

Here are the search results on nasolabial angle, nose attractiveness, rhinoplasty, and ideal measurements from PubMed studies:

## Key Studies on Ideal Nasolabial Angle in Rhinoplasty

### General Population Preferences
In a study of the general population, the ideal and most aesthetic nasolabial angle ranged from 100.9 to 108.9 degrees in the female nose and 90.7 to 103.3 degrees in the male nose.(no content)The most aesthetic female nasolabial angle was 104.9±4.0 degrees, and the most aesthetic male nasolabial angle was 97.0±6.3 degrees.(no content)Male subjects, younger volunteers, Native Americans, and African Americans preferred more acute male nasolabial angles (90 degrees), while female subjects, volunteers older than 50 years, college graduates, those with a previous rhinoplasty, and Caucasian and Asian subjects preferred more obtuse male nasolabial angles.

### Expert Analysis
The nasolabial angle is the angle between the line drawn through the midpoint of the nostril aperture and a line drawn perpendicular to the Frankfort horizontal plane while intersecting subnasale. Previous analysis yielded closer ranges between men and women of 96 and 98 degrees, respectively. Further refinement used opinions of seasoned rhinoplasty surgeons from the Rhinoplasty Society.

### Cross-Cultural Findings
The perception of an ideal nose is influenced by a variety of factors, with demographic characteristics playing a significant role. The nasolabial angle (NLA) is considered one of the defining features shaping the nose. A 2024 study captured the perception of the ideal nasolabial angle among Canadian, Saudi, Kuwaiti, and Lebanese populations.

### Literature Range
Various studies have reported on the ideal nasolabial angle, with ranges from 90° to 120° often cited, with slightly more acute angles in males (90° to 95°) compared to females (95° to 105°) advocated as ideal.(no content)The nasolabial angle is defined as the angle between the line drawn through the midpoint of the nostril aperture and a line drawn perpendicular to the Frankfurt horizontal and intersecting the subnasale. An arbitrary range of 90 to 115 degrees for the nasolabial angle is usually stated in the literature.

### Rhinoplasty Outcomes
In an Indian population study, significant improvements were observed in the nasolabial angle from 92.9 ± 16.4 to 101.6 ± 10.4 immediately post-op and 110.3 ± 9.8 at 6-months follow-up.

### Psychological Considerations
Nasolabial angle, nasofacial angle, alar width, and intercanthal distance were not different between rhinoplasty candidates and controls. Four major aesthetic nasal proportions were statistically similar in both groups. Surprisingly, the patients having rhinoplasty showed a mean width-to-length ratio closer to aesthetic ideal, suggesting that applying for rhinoplasty may have strong psychological reasons (e.g., body dysmorphic symptoms) compared with realistic aesthetic appraisals.

Why is a positive tilt more attractive than a negative tilt among males: | Looksmax.org - Men's Self-Improvement & Aesthetics","url":"https://looksmax.org/threads/what-is-an-eye-canthal-tilt-why-is-a-positive-tilt-more-attractive-than-a-negative-tilt-among-males.1215932/"},{"title":"Is Medial Canthal Tilt a Powerful Cue for Facial Attractiveness? | Semantic Scholar","url":"https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Is-Medial-Canthal-Tilt-a-Powerful-Cue-for-Facial-Bashour-Geist/ee5d1e979be585445053fe420ac57dedd15eaf43"},{"title":"Upward Canthal Tilt: Characteristics and Perceptions of Beauty","url":"https://www.dr-mfo.com/upward-canthal-tilt/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what research shows about canthal tilt and eye attractiveness:

## Key Research Findings

### Primary Study: Bashour & Geist (2007)
Female faces with accentuated medial canthal tilt were preferred 93% of the time over unmodified faces (p < 0.0001). The study concluded that medial canthal tilt appears to be a powerful cue used in judging human female facial attractiveness.(no content)The study was designed to identify medial canthal tilt as an important cue in evaluating human female facial attractiveness. Researchers used SuperLab Pro software and had judges make forced choices between unmodified faces and faces with digitally accentuated medial canthal tilt using Adobe Photoshop.(no content)The power of canthal tilt as an attractiveness cue may be due to its relation to the neotenic and sexually dimorphic cue of palpebral fissure inclination.

### Definitions and Classifications

The canthal tilt is the angle of the lateral canthus (outside corner of eye) in relation to the medial canthus (inside corner of eye). A positive canthal tilt means the lateral canthus is higher on the face in relation to the medial canthus. In contrast, a negative canthal tilt means the lateral canthus is lower on the face than the medial canthus.(no content)According to a study by Codner et al. (2008), canthal tilt was considered positive when the lateral canthus is above the medial canthus, neutral when they are at the same level, and negative when the lateral canthus is lower.

### Sexual Dimorphism

Canthal tilt is mildly sexually dimorphic, with women being more likely to have upward slanting eyes than men, at least among Caucasians.(no content)This phenomenon is explained by the fact that a steeper palpebral fissure inclination is a neonatal and sexually dimorphic feature.

### Ethnic Variations

According to Rhee et al., an attractive Korean face has a canthal tilt of 8.87°, which falls into the class II category (more than 5°).(no content)A positive canthal tilt is more common among East Asians, however female East Asian faces judged to be particularly attractive have a less pronounced positive canthal tilt than what is typical for those populations.

### Male Attractiveness

Research by Penčić et al. (2019) highlighted that in males, an ideal canthal tilt is neutral or slightly positive, as it enhances perceptions of youthfulness and facial balance. Conversely, a negative canthal tilt is often linked with signs of aging and less favorable aesthetic outcomes.

### Association with Youth

As we age, the tissues around the eyes tend to lose elasticity, and the lateral canthus can droop slightly, leading to a more neutral or even downward canthal tilt. Therefore, an upward tilt can be subconsciously associated with youth and vitality.

The key PubMed reference is: **Bashour, M., & Geist, C. (2007). "Is medial canthal tilt a powerful cue for facial attractiveness?" Ophthalmic Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery, 23(1), 52-56.** (PMID: 17237692)

Miranda - 2021 - International Journal of Dermatology - Wiley Online Library","url":"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/ijd.15518"},{"title":"Skin Aging and Type I Collagen: A Systematic Review of Interventions with Potential Collagen-Related Effects","url":"https://www.mdpi.com/2079-9284/12/4/129"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of the research on collagen supplementation for skin elasticity and wrinkles:

## Summary of Meta-Analyses and Clinical Trials

### Positive Findings

Several meta-analyses have found favorable results for collagen supplementation:

A grouped analysis of studies showed favorable results of hydrolyzed collagen supplementation compared with placebo in terms of skin hydration, elasticity, and wrinkles.(no content)This meta-analysis included 19 studies with a total of 1,125 participants aged between 20 and 70 years (95% women).(no content)Based on results, ingestion of hydrolyzed collagen for 90 days is effective in reducing skin aging, as it reduces wrinkles and improves skin elasticity and hydration.(no content)A more recent systematic review and meta-analysis analyzed 26 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) involving 1721 patients to assess the effects of hydrolyzed collagen (HC) supplementation on skin hydration and elasticity.(no content)The results showed that HC supplementation significantly improved skin hydration (test for overall effect: Z = 4.94, p < 0.00001) and elasticity (test for overall effect: Z = 4.49, p < 0.00001) compared to the placebo group.(no content)The beneficial effects were significant after 8 weeks or more of HC supplementation.

### Critical Findings (2025 Meta-Analysis)

However, the most recent systematic review and meta-analysis is the first to report no effect of collagen supplements on skin aging. Key findings include:

A total of 23 RCTs with 1474 participants were analyzed. In a meta-analysis of all 23 RCTs, collagen supplements significantly improved skin hydration, elasticity, and wrinkles.(no content)However, in the sensitivity analysis, excluding outlier studies showing an extreme beneficial effect, collagen supplements showed no significant improvement of wrinkles and a decreased effect for hydration and elasticity.(no content)In the subgroup meta-analysis by funding source, studies not receiving funding from pharmaceutical companies revealed no effect of collagen supplements for improving skin hydration, elasticity, and wrinkles, while those receiving funding from pharmaceutical companies did show significant effects. Similarly, high-quality studies revealed no significant effect in all categories, while low-quality studies revealed a significant improvement in elasticity.

### Study Limitations

The interventions used in the included studies exhibited some heterogeneity, primarily because of the distinct measurement units and composition of the supplementation. The number of patients included in some studies was less than 40. Therefore, a small sample size may have resulted in a slight risk of bias.(no content)Overall, the findings suggest that HC supplementation can have positive effects on skin health, but further large-scale randomized control trials are necessary to confirm these findings.

### Conclusion

The evidence on collagen supplementation for skin health is mixed. While earlier meta-analyses showed positive effects, there is currently no clinical evidence to support the use of collagen supplements to prevent or treat skin aging when considering study quality and funding sources, according to the most recent analysis.

Links: [{"title":"A new data-driven mathematical model dissociates attractiveness from sexual dimorphism of human faces | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-73472-8"},{"title":"How and why patterns of sexual dimorphism in human faces vary across the world | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-021-85402-3"},{"title":"Distinctiveness and femininity, rather than symmetry and masculinity, affect facial attractiveness across the world - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1090513823000879"},{"title":"How and why patterns of sexual dimorphism in human faces vary across the world - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7966798/"},{"title":"Human preferences for sexually dimorphic faces may be evolutionarily novel | PNAS","url":"https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1409643111"},{"title":"Human preferences for sexually dimorphic faces may be evolutionarily novel - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4210032/"},{"title":"A new data-driven mathematical model dissociates attractiveness from sexual dimorphism of human faces - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7538911/"},{"title":"Facial attractiveness and preference of sexual dimorphism: A comparison across five populations - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10427909/"},{"title":"Influence of sexual dimorphism on the attractiveness evaluation of one’s own face - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0042698920300158"},{"title":"Facial attractiveness and preference of sexual dimorphism: A comparison across five populations | Evolutionary Human Sciences | Cambridge Core","url":"https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/evolutionary-human-sciences/article/facial-attractiveness-and-preference-of-sexual-dimorphism-a-comparison-across-five-populations/855665E31FE47492B4F5356B5F34FE7F"}]

Here are the search results on sexual dimorphism, facial features, and attractiveness:

## Key Research Findings

### General Overview
Human facial attractiveness is evaluated by using multiple cues. Among others, sexual dimorphism (i.e., masculinity for male faces/femininity for female faces) is an influential factor of perceived attractiveness.(no content)Several facial morphologies and skin properties have been identified as critical cues to attractiveness, including averageness, symmetry, and skin colour.

### Femininity in Female Faces
Male faces with more masculine traits and female faces with more feminine traits are perceived as more attractive. In particular, the preference for femininity in female faces is widespread across cultures and ages.(no content)In all samples, women's perceived femininity was positively related to their perceived attractiveness. Women found perceived masculinity in men attractive only in Czechia and Colombia, two distant populations. The association between perceived sexual dimorphism and attractiveness is thus potentially universal only for women.

### Masculinity in Male Faces - Mixed Results
The preference for masculinity in male faces varies more; some studies demonstrated a masculinity preference while some other studies showed a femininity preference, or no obvious relationship.(no content)Masculinity in male faces can be associated with negative personality traits and behaviours; male-looking facial features are generally less preferred because these features conceive emotionally negative male personalities such as aggressiveness or dominance. Likewise, highly masculine faces are perceived as less emotionally warm and less cooperative than more feminine faces.

### Cross-Cultural Variation
Human populations vary substantially and unexpectedly in both the magnitude and direction of facial sexually dimorphic traits. In particular, European and South American populations display larger levels of facial sexual dimorphism than African populations.(no content)There were no significant preferences among the Aka, Shuar, or Tchimba populations. Randomization tests revealed an average male preference for feminized female faces among the Canadian, Fijian, Hangzhouvian, Kadazan, Shanghainese, Cree, and UK populations.

### Evolutionary Perspectives
A large literature proposes that preferences for exaggerated sex typicality in human faces (masculinity/femininity) reflect a long evolutionary history of sexual and social selection. These data challenge the hypothesis that facial dimorphism was an important ancestral signal of heritable mate value.(no content)Such a trade-off between preference for a good gene and a good dad makes male facial attractiveness judgments more complicated.

### Recent Multi-Population Studies
Researchers investigated preferences in both sexes for three structural components of facial beauty: symmetry, sexual dimorphism, and distinctiveness. Based on a large sample of faces (n = 1550) from 10 populations across the world (Brazil, Cameroon, Czechia, Colombia, India, Namibia, Romania, Turkey, UK, and Vietnam), distinctiveness negatively affects the perception of attractiveness in both sexes.(no content)In humans, the femininity of women's faces is considered attractive to men, but preferences for masculinity in men's faces vary across studies.

Links: [{"title":"Topical tretinoin for treating photoaging: A systematic review of randomized controlled trials - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9112391/"},{"title":"Tretinoin for Photodamaged Facial Skin: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12615114/"},{"title":"Comparative efficacy of topical interventions for facial photoaging: a network meta-analysis | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-12597-0"},{"title":"Retinoids in Anti-Aging Skincare with Dr. Face Technologies: Unraveling Molecular Mechanisms and Clinical Evidence[v1] | Preprints.org","url":"https://www.preprints.org/manuscript/202506.1024/v1/download"},{"title":"Topical tretinoin for treating photoaging: A systematic review of randomized controlled trials - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35620028/"},{"title":"Tretinoin for Photodamaged Facial Skin: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials | Dermatology Practical & Conceptual","url":"https://dpcj.org/index.php/dpc/article/view/5172"},{"title":"A randomized, controlled comparative study of the wrinkle reduction benefits of a cosmetic niacinamide/peptide/retinyl propionate product regimen vs. a prescription 0·02% tretinoin product regimen - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2841824/"},{"title":"Retinoids in the treatment of skin aging: an overview of clinical efficacy and safety - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2699641/"},{"title":"A comparative study of the effects of retinol and retinoic acid on histological, molecular, and clinical properties of human skin - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26578346/"},{"title":"A randomized, double-blind, controlled comparative trial of the anti-aging properties of non-prescription tri-retinol 1.1% vs. prescription tretinoin 0.025% - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22206079/"}]

Here are the key findings from clinical research on tretinoin for anti-aging and wrinkle reduction from PubMed:

## Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses

### 2024 Meta-Analysis
A systematic review identified eight trials with 1,361 patients (median age range 29–76 years; average follow-up duration, 16 weeks to 2 years).(no content)A significant improvement in fine facial wrinkles was observed following tretinoin treatment (MD: 0.412; 95% CI: 0.233–0.590; P<0.001).(no content)The conclusion was that topical tretinoin is a safe and effective treatment for fine and coarse facial wrinkles resulting from photodamage.

### 2022 Systematic Review
A systematic search examined 180 studies, of which 7 randomized controlled trials were included in the review.(no content)All studies consistently reported that topical tretinoin was efficacious in improving clinical appearance of photoaging in terms of wrinkling, mottled hyperpigmentation, sallowness, and lentigines as early as 1 month and lasting after 24 months.(no content)The review concluded that topical tretinoin is a safe and effective therapeutic modality for long-term treatment of photoaging.

## Mechanism of Action
Tretinoin, a metabolite of retinoids, has the ability to regulate proliferation and differentiation of epidermal cells, induce formation of new collagen, prevent collagen loss, and block induction of MMP (matrix metalloproteinases).(no content)When applied prior to UV exposure, tretinoin inhibits activator protein-1 (AP-1) activity, which drives collagen-degrading MMPs. It also stimulates collagen synthesis by upregulating type I procollagen expression.

## Dosage and Safety
The concentration of tretinoin in studies varied from 0.025% to 0.1%, with treatment duration ranging from 3 months up to 24 months.(no content)Tretinoin cream 0.02% is now recognized by the FDA for the treatment of photoaging.(no content)All studies indicated that topical tretinoin was safe and well tolerated in all patients.

## Comparative Effectiveness
A Bayesian network meta-analysis showed isotretinoin, retinol, and tretinoin significantly improved fine wrinkles, with isotretinoin ranked highest.(no content)Safety analysis indicated tretinoin had the most favorable profile, and isotretinoin and tretinoin emerged as the most balanced treatments across efficacy and safety.(no content)Tretinoin is considered the benchmark prescription topical therapy for improving fine facial wrinkles, but skin tolerance issues can affect patient compliance.

Links: [{"title":"Revisiting the science of attraction: Averageness is key to facial beauty, study finds","url":"https://www.psypost.org/revisiting-the-science-of-attraction-averageness-is-key-to-facial-beauty-global-study-finds/"},{"title":"Beauty is in the ease of the beholding: A neurophysiological test of the averageness theory of facial attractiveness - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4053512/"},{"title":"Averageness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Averageness"},{"title":"Further evidence that averageness and femininity, rather than symmetry and masculinity, predict facial attractiveness judgments | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-86974-0"},{"title":"Objectively measured facial traits predict in-person evaluations of facial attractiveness and prosociality in speed-dating partners - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S109051382300051X"},{"title":"Facial attractiveness: evolutionary based research - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3130383/"},{"title":"Dissociating averageness and attractiveness: attractive faces are not always average - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18085954/"},{"title":"Attractiveness of facial averageness and symmetry in non-western cultures: in search of biologically based standards of beauty - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11430245/"},{"title":"Beauty is in the ease of the beholding: a neurophysiological test of the averageness theory of facial attractiveness - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24326966/"},{"title":"Preference for facial averageness: Evidence for a common mechanism in human and macaque infants | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/srep46303"}]

Here's what the research shows about facial averageness and attractiveness:

## Key Findings

### The Averageness Theory
"Averageness theory claims that faces are perceived as being attractive when their facial configuration approximates the mathematical average facial configuration of the population."(no content)Multiple studies have shown that adult humans perceive faces possessing high averageness as highly attractive, whereas faces with low averageness (faces that deviate from the average facial configuration of a population) are perceived as unattractive.

### Major Research Studies

**Global Study (2024):** A global study on 1,550 faces found attractiveness is less about symmetry, more about averageness and distinctiveness. Faces closer to a population's average are seen as more attractive, challenging traditional beliefs on beauty standards.(no content)The researchers used a total of 1,550 images of faces from 10 different countries, including Brazilian, British, Cameroonian, Czech, Colombian, Namibian, Romanian, Turkish, Indian, and Vietnamese faces.

**Recent 2025 Study:** Research findings add to a growing body of research suggesting that averageness is a key shape characteristic for facial attractiveness judgments and that there is little evidence for a significant role of symmetry or male masculinity. These results are consistent with other recent work suggesting that averageness and femininity, rather than symmetry and masculinity, predict facial attractiveness.

### Cross-Cultural Evidence
Increasing the averageness of individual faces, by warping those faces towards an averaged composite of the same race and sex, increased the attractiveness of both Chinese and Japanese faces. Decreasing averageness by moving the faces away from an average shape decreased attractiveness.(no content)These findings show that preferences for facial averageness and symmetry are not restricted to Western cultures, consistent with the view that they are biologically based.

### Biological Basis
A possible evolutionary explanation for averageness is koinophilia, in which sexually-reproducing animals seek mates with primarily average features, because extreme and uncommon features are likely to indicate disadvantageous mutations.(no content)Human adults and infants show a preference for average faces, which could stem from a general processing mechanism and may be shared among primates.(no content)In experiments, 12-month-old human infants preferred faces closer to the average than faces farther from it. Similarly, 3-month-old rhesus macaques viewing macaque faces also looked longer to faces closer to the average.

### Notable Caveats
Although the averageness hypothesis of facial attractiveness proposes that the attractiveness of faces is mostly a consequence of their averageness, one study has shown that caricaturing highly attractive faces makes them mathematically less average but more attractive.(no content)The results of these experiments conclusively support the proposal that there are specific nonaverage characteristics that are particularly attractive.

- PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9452610/"},{"title":"Historical Tools of Anthropometric Facial Assessment: A Systematic Raw Data Analysis on the Applicability of the Neoclassical Canons and Golden Ratio | Aesthetic Surgery Journal | Oxford Academic","url":"https://academic.oup.com/asj/article/42/1/NP1/6369423?login=false"},{"title":"Neoclassical Facial Canons in Young Adults | Request PDF","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233404730_Neoclassical_Facial_Canons_in_Young_Adults"},{"title":"Canons of ideal facial dimensions and facial beauty - Cosmoderma","url":"https://cosmoderma.org/canons-of-ideal-facial-dimensions-and-facial-beauty/"},{"title":"Does 3-dimensional facial attractiveness relate to golden ratio, neoclassical canons, ‘ideal’ ratios and ‘ideal’ angles? | Maxillofacial Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery | Full Text","url":"https://jkamprs.springeropen.com/articles/10.1186/s40902-022-00358-2"},{"title":"Associations of Facial Proportionality, Attractiveness, and Character Traits","url":"https://neuroaesthetics.med.upenn.edu/assets/user-content/documents/publications/associations-of-facial-proportionality,.38.pdf"},{"title":"The validity of three neo-classical facial canons in young adults originating from the Arabian Peninsula - PMC","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4369102/"},{"title":"(PDF) Computation of a face attractiveness index based on neoclassical canons, symmetry, and golden ratios","url":"https://www.academia.edu/15350020/Computation_of_a_face_attractiveness_index_based_on_neoclassical_canons_symmetry_and_golden_ratios"},{"title":"Evaluation of Facial Beauty Using Anthropometric Proportions - Milutinovic - 2014 - The Scientific World Journal - Wiley Online Library","url":"https://www.hindawi.com/journals/tswj/2014/428250/"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of research on midface ratio, facial thirds, attractiveness, and neoclassical canons:

## Key Findings on Facial Proportions and Attractiveness

### Neoclassical Canons and Facial Thirds

"Canons of ideal facial dimensions have been known since antiquity (ancient Greek and European Renaissance art) and remain relevant. Horizontal (into thirds) and vertical (into fifths) anatomical proportions can provide a valuable framework for cosmetic interventions."(no content)Leonardo da Vinci described dividing the face into equal thirds in his writings on human anatomy.(no content)Canon 2, the rule that states that the face can be divided into equal thirds with the nose occupying the middle third, varied between ethnic groups (P = 0.033) and from the ideal value. On average, all male faces had a larger upper face compared with the midface.

### Validity of Neoclassical Canons

Neoclassical canons were invalidated due to the differences in transcultural facial structures such as Chinese, Arabian, Turkish, Croatian, Korean-American, and Greek. However, neoclassical canons were more valid in whites than in Asians.(no content)Although individuals may be esthetically pleasing, they do not exhibit equal facial thirds or conform to orbital or orbito-nasal canons. The three neoclassical canons studied could not be validated in young adults originating from the Arabian Peninsula.

### Midface and Attractiveness

A significantly positive association was observed between the middle facial height and VAS (Visual Analogue Scale) scores in the male models (p < 0.05).(no content)The neoclassical canon assumptions hold that ideal horizontal third proportions are in perfect 1:1:1 ratios. However, work by Farkas demonstrated normal proportions for males and females differ from the canon and each other, with male proportions being 31.0%, 30.5%, and 38.5%, and female proportions being 29.5%, 32.4%, and 38.2% for the upper, middle, and lower thirds of the face, respectively.(no content)Only 1% of the study population had equal facial thirds, the midface was the shortest of the facial thirds and the male gender generally had larger mean values of the facial dimensions than the female gender.

### Golden Ratio Findings

The results showed that the facial golden ratio was not valid in modern beautiful women.(no content)More than half of the measurements (42/77) in females and thirty-two measurements in males were found to be significantly different from the ideal target value (p < 0.05) upon the comparison of the attractive faces with golden ratio, neoclassical canons, 'ideal' ratios and 'ideal' angles.

### Attractive Facial Characteristics

An attractive female face can be interpreted as having a shorter and broader nose, broader inter-endocanthus and inter-exocanthus width, shorter lower facial third, thicker vermillion of both upper and lower lips, shorter upper lip, flatter labio-mental fold and retrusive mandible comparing to the recommended ideal faces.(no content)Studies showed significant difference between anonymous and attractive females. Attractive females showed smaller face in general and uniformity of the facial thirds and fifths, and most of the facial parameters meet the criteria of the ideal proportions.

results:
Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of research on midface ratio, facial thirds, attractiveness, and neoclassical canons:

## Key Findings on Facial Proportions and Attractiveness

### Neoclassical Canons and Facial Thirds

"Canons of ideal facial dimensions have been known since antiquity (ancient Greek and European Renaissance art) and remain relevant. Horizontal (into thirds) and vertical (into fifths) anatomical proportions can provide a valuable framework for cosmetic interventions."(no content)Leonardo da Vinci described dividing the face into equal thirds in his writings on human anatomy.(no content)Canon 2, the rule that states that the face can be divided into equal thirds with the nose occupying the middle third, varied between ethnic groups (P = 0.033) and from the ideal value. On average, all male faces had a larger upper face compared with the midface.

### Validity of Neoclassical Canons

Neoclassical canons were invalidated due to the differences in transcultural facial structures such as Chinese, Arabian, Turkish, Croatian, Korean-American, and Greek. However, neoclassical canons were more valid in whites than in Asians.(no content)Although individuals may be esthetically pleasing, they do not exhibit equal facial thirds or conform to orbital or orbito-nasal canons. The three neoclassical canons studied could not be validated in young adults originating from the Arabian Peninsula.

### Midface and Attractiveness

A significantly positive association was observed between the middle facial height and VAS (Visual Analogue Scale) scores in the male models (p < 0.05).(no content)The neoclassical canon assumptions hold that ideal horizontal third proportions are in perfect 1:1:1 ratios. However, work by Farkas demonstrated normal proportions for males and females differ from the canon and each other, with male proportions being 31.0%, 30.5%, and 38.5%, and female proportions being 29.5%, 32.4%, and 38.2% for the upper, middle, and lower thirds of the face, respectively.(no content)Only 1% of the study population had equal facial thirds, the midface was the shortest of the facial thirds and the male gender generally had larger mean values of the facial dimensions than the female gender.

### Golden Ratio Findings

The results showed that the facial golden ratio was not valid in modern beautiful women.(no content)More than half of the measurements (42/77) in females and thirty-two measurements in males were found to be significantly different from the ideal target value (p < 0.05) upon the comparison of the attractive faces with golden ratio, neoclassical canons, 'ideal' ratios and 'ideal' angles.

### Attractive Facial Characteristics

An attractive female face can be interpreted as having a shorter and broader nose, broader inter-endocanthus and inter-exocanthus width, shorter lower facial third, thicker vermillion of both upper and lower lips, shorter upper lip, flatter labio-mental fold and retrusive mandible comparing to the recommended ideal faces.(no content)Studies showed significant difference between anonymous and attractive females. Attractive females showed smaller face in general and uniformity of the facial thirds and fifths, and most of the facial parameters meet the criteria of the ideal proportions.

Here are the results from my search for vitamin D and skin health dermatology studies on PubMed:

## Key Studies and Reviews Found:

### Reviews on Vitamin D and Skin

1. **"Vitamin D and the Skin: An Update for Dermatologists"** (2018)
   - Vitamin D plays a key role in skeletal and cardiovascular disorders, cancers, central nervous system diseases, reproductive diseases, infections, and autoimmune and dermatological disorders.
   - The two main sources of vitamin D are sun exposure and oral intake, including vitamin D supplementation and dietary intake. Multiple factors are linked to vitamin D status, such as Fitzpatrick skin type, sex, body mass index, physical activity, alcohol intake, and vitamin D receptor polymorphisms.
   - Maintaining a vitamin D serum concentration within normal levels is warranted in atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, vitiligo, polymorphous light eruption, and mycosis fungoides.

2. **"Vitamin D and the Skin: A Review for Dermatologists"** (2019)
   - In recent years, the growing interest in the role played by vitamin D in skin disease has given rise to many studies. Of particular interest are the latest discoveries about the role of vitamin D in skin diseases such as lupus erythematosus, ichthyosis, atopic dermatitis, hidradenitis suppurativa, acne, alopecia areata, androgenetic alopecia, melanoma, and nonmelanoma skin cancer.

### Clinical Trials

3. **Psoriasis Clinical Trial** (JAMA Dermatology, 2023)
   - The trial was conducted at the University Hospital of North Norway. Adults with active plaque psoriasis and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels of less than 24 ng/mL were included. The intervention was vitamin D (cholecalciferol, 100,000 IU loading dose, followed by 20,000 IU/week) or placebo for 4 months.
   - The results showed that vitamin D supplementation did not affect psoriasis severity. Low baseline severity scores may explain the lack of measurable effect.

4. **Atopic Dermatitis Clinical Trial**
   - Sixty AD patients were included in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial study. They were randomly divided into two groups and treated for 60 days: group vitamin D (n=30), and placebo group (n=30). Group D received 1600 IU cholecalciferol (vitamin D).
   - According to SCORAD and TIS value index, the vitamin D group showed significant improvement in patients with mild, moderate and severe AD (P<0.05).

5. **Severe Atopic Dermatitis Trial** (2020)
   - Vitamin D supplementation with standard treatment yielded positive clinical outcomes in mild and moderate atopic dermatitis; however, the potential benefit of vitamin D in severe cases remains unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of vitamin D supplementation on response to standard treatment in pediatrics with severe atopic dermatitis.

6. **Melanoma Clinical Trial (ViDMe Trial)** (2024)
   - Cutaneous melanoma is the most lethal form of skin cancer. Previous studies have shown that low vitamin D levels at the time of diagnosis are associated with thicker tumours and worse outcome. This study examined whether monthly high-dose vitamin D supplementation after diagnosis could improve outcomes.
   - The clinical trial included 436 patients with CM who were randomly allocated into two groups - 218 patients received placebo and 218 received monthly oral vitamin D.

### Topical Vitamin D

7. **"Off-label uses of topical vitamin D in dermatology: a systematic review"**
   - A total of 165 articles met the inclusion criteria. A moderate to strong recommendation was given for the use of topical vitamin D in combination with corticosteroids and phototherapy in vitiligo and as monotherapy for various ichthyoses, morphea, pityriasis alba, prurigo nodularis, and polymorphous light eruption.

### Vitamin D Synthesis in Skin

8. **"Vitamin D and the skin"**
   - Vitamin D is a fat-soluble nutrient that humans obtain through the diet and by synthesis in the skin upon exposure to ultraviolet B. Vitamin D is then converted by the liver to 25-hydroxyvitamin D, its major circulating form. Under the influence of parathyroid hormone, the kidney then converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, the biologically active, hormonal form.

Links: [{"title":"Frontiers | Efficacy and safety of oral minoxidil in the treatment of alopecia: a single-arm rate meta-analysis and systematic review","url":"https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/pharmacology/articles/10.3389/fphar.2025.1556705/full"},{"title":"Topical Minoxidil: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Its Efficacy in Androgenetic Alopecia - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26380504/"},{"title":"Efficacy and safety of oral minoxidil in the treatment of alopecia: a single-arm rate meta-analysis and systematic review - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12188453/"},{"title":"Injectable Minoxidil for Hair Loss Disorders: A Systematic Review - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/39630673/"},{"title":"Oral minoxidil treatment for hair loss: A review of efficacy and safety - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32622136/"},{"title":"Minoxidil: a comprehensive review - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34159872/"},{"title":"The effectiveness of treatments for androgenetic alopecia: A systematic review and meta-analysis - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28396101/"},{"title":"Efficacy and safety of oral minoxidil in the treatment of alopecia: a single-arm rate meta-analysis and systematic review - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/40567364/"},{"title":"Minoxidil and its use in hair disorders: a review - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6691938/"},{"title":"Review of oral minoxidil as treatment of hair disorders: in search of the perfect dose - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33660357/"}]

Here are the results of systematic reviews on minoxidil efficacy for hair growth from PubMed and related sources:

## Key Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses

### Topical Minoxidil
Results showed that minoxidil is more effective than placebo in promoting total and nonvellus hair growth (mean difference [MD], 16.68; 95% confidence interval [CI], 9.34-24.03 and MD, 20.90; 95% CI, 9.07-32.74).(no content)Topical minoxidil has become a mainstay in the treatment of androgenetic alopecia (AGA), though relatively few reviews of its efficacy have been published.

### Oral Minoxidil
A recent 2025 meta-analysis from PubMed/PMC found that a total of 2,933 patients from 27 studies were included in the analysis. Among the participants, 35% (95% CI: 22%-49%) experienced significant symptom improvement, 47% (95% CI: 38%-55%) showed symptom improvement, and 26% (95% CI: 16%-37%) had stable symptoms.(no content)This systematic review and meta-analysis indicate that individuals with hair loss may derive benefits from oral minoxidil, particularly at doses exceeding 1 mg. Nonetheless, additional research or data is essential to definitively establish its efficacy and safety.

### Comparative Efficacy
A meta-analysis strongly suggests that minoxidil, finasteride, and low-level laser light therapy are effective for promoting hair growth in men with androgenetic alopecia and that minoxidil is effective in women with androgenetic alopecia.(no content)After 6 months of administration, minoxidil 5 mg/day was significantly more effective than topical 5% and 2% in male AGA.

### Dosing Considerations
Oral minoxidil has proven to be a successful and well-tolerated alternative for patients with hair loss, including those with poor adherence to other therapies. Different dosing regimens have been utilized in scarring and non-scarring alopecia, varying from 0.25 to 5 mg daily.(no content)Available literature suggests women require lower doses, from 0.25 to 2.5 mg daily, while men require higher doses for maximal efficacy, from 1.25 to 5 mg a day.

### Injectable Minoxidil
This systematic review demonstrates injectable minoxidil is an efficacious and safe treatment for androgenetic alopecia, with variable efficacy and safety for treating alopecia areata.

ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0899900722002040"},{"title":"Effects of creatine supplementation on muscle strength gains—a meta-analysis and systematic review","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/398043159_Effects_of_creatine_supplementation_on_muscle_strength_gains-a_meta-analysis_and_systematic_review"},{"title":"International Society of Sports Nutrition position stand: safety and efficacy of creatine supplementation in exercise, sport, and medicine | Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition","url":"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s12970-017-0173-z"},{"title":"Impact of creatine supplementation and exercise training in older adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12506341/"}]

Here are the key findings from recent meta-analyses on creatine supplementation and muscle growth efficacy:

## Key Meta-Analysis Findings

### Muscle Strength Gains

In comparison with a placebo, creatine supplementation combined with resistance training significantly increased upper-body (WMD = 4.43 kg, p < 0.001) and lower-body strength.(no content)This meta-analysis concluded that creatine supplementation with resistance training enhances upper- and lower-body muscle strength in adults aged < 50, with greater benefits likely to be seen in males than females.

### Sex Differences

Males showed average increases of 4.95 kg in upper-body strength and 11.68 kg in lower-body strength with creatine supplementation plus resistance training.(no content)In contrast, females did not show significant improvements in muscle strength, with average increases of only 1.54 kg in upper-body strength and 8.03 kg in lower-body strength, indicating no notable differences compared with placebo and resistance training alone.

### Lean Body Mass

Creatine supplementation (with and without exercise interventions) increased lean body mass by approximately 0.7 kg. When creatine supplementation was combined with resistance training, LBM increased by ~1.1 kg regardless of age or sex differences.(no content)Overall, creatine supplementation combined with resistance training increased LBM (1.1–1.5 kg) in adults regardless of age (young, middle-aged, and older adults) and in men, with high credibility evidence. A non-significant LBM increase for women was found (0.5–0.6 kg when combined with exercise).

### Regional Muscle Hypertrophy

The pooled analysis indicated that creatine supplementation enhances regional skeletal muscle hypertrophy when combined with structured resistance training. However, compared to a placebo, the magnitude of this effect was trivial to small (ES = 0.11), suggesting the practical significance on an individual level is likely small.(no content)Some evidence suggests that at least some of the lean mass gains from creatine supplementation can be attributed to water retention.

### Older Adults

Creatine supplementation with strength training (2–3 sessions/week) for 7–52 weeks significantly increases lean tissue mass (about 1.37 kg) in addition to upper- and lower-body muscle strength in older adults (57–70 years old) compared to strength training alone.

### Dosage Considerations

Highly consistent results from both conventional meta-analysis and RVE sensitivity analysis indicate that low-dose supplementation regimens yield superior muscle strength gain effects.(no content)Based on the current meta-analysis, creatine monohydrate is well-studied (n = 89 RCTs), effective (p < 0.001), and has a well-developed safety profile.

Links: [{"title":"Effect of dietary supplementation with omega-3 fatty acid and gamma-linolenic acid on acne vulgaris: a randomised, double-blind, controlled trial - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24553997/"},{"title":"Exploring the potential of omega-3 fatty acids in acne patients: A prospective intervention study - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38982829/"},{"title":"Deficit of Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Acne Patients-A Cross-Sectional Pilot Study in a German Cohort - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38672789/"},{"title":"Effects of fish oil supplementation on inflammatory acne - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3543297/"},{"title":"Effects of fish oil supplementation on inflammatory acne - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23206895/"},{"title":"Exploring the potential of omega‐3 fatty acids in acne patients: A prospective intervention study - Guertler - 2024 - Journal of Cosmetic Dermatology - Wiley Online Library","url":"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jocd.16434"},{"title":"Is Oral Omega-3 Effective in Reducing Mucocutaneous Side Effects of Isotretinoin in Patients with Acne Vulgaris? - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5996413/"},{"title":"The Potential Uses of Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Dermatology: A Review - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32463305/"},{"title":"Review of Omega-3 Fatty Acid Dietary Supplementation in Cutaneous Inflammatory Disorders: This review evaluates oral Omega-3 supplementation’s impact on acne, psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, and rosacea, revealing mixed efficacy and underscoring the need for stronger clinical evidence. | Journal of Integrative Dermatology","url":"https://jintegrativederm.org/doi/10.64550/joid.dc39qy52"},{"title":"Acne vulgaris, mental health and omega-3 fatty acids: a report of cases - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18851733/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what the research shows about omega-3 fish oil, skin health, inflammation, and acne from clinical trials indexed on PubMed:

## Key Clinical Trial Findings

### Randomized Controlled Trial (2014)
After 10 weeks of omega-3 fatty acid or γ-linoleic acid supplementation, inflammatory and non-inflammatory acne lesions decreased significantly.(no content)Patient subjective assessment of improvement showed a similar result.

### Prospective Intervention Study (2024)
Omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) are essential nutrients known for their anti-inflammatory properties, which involve reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines, eicosanoids, and insulin-like growth factor-1. This suggests their potential to alleviate acne severity, especially when deficits are present.(no content)In a 16-week study, 60 patients adhered to a Mediterranean diet, incorporating oral algae-derived ω-3 FA supplementation (600 mg DHA/300 mg EPA week 1-8, 800 mg DHA/400 mg EPA week 8-16).(no content)Objective improvements in both inflammatory and non-inflammatory lesions were observed (p < 0.001). While self-reported appearance worsened in four patients, overall quality of life improved (p < 0.001), particularly in acne papulopustulosa patients.

### Fish Oil Supplementation Study
Given that acne is a rare condition in societies with higher consumption of omega-3 relative to omega-6 fatty acids, supplementation with omega-3 may suppress inflammatory cytokine production and thereby reduce acne severity.(no content)In one study, 13 individuals with inflammatory acne were given three grams of fish oil containing 930 mg of EPA for 12 weeks.(no content)There was no significant change in acne grading and inflammatory counts at week 12 compared to baseline. However, there was a broad range of response to the intervention on an individual basis. The results showed that acne severity improved in 8 individuals, worsened in 4, and remained unchanged in 1.

### Cross-Sectional Study (2024)
A pilot study demonstrated a deficit of ω-3 FAs in a German acne cohort. Higher ω-3 FA levels were observed in patients with regular legume intake and oral ω-3 FA supplementation. Further prospective studies are needed to investigate whether the clinical severity of acne improves in patients with normal omega-3 levels.

## Broader Dermatological Applications
A review of 38 studies reported benefits for omega-3 supplementation in the treatment of psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, acne, and skin ulcers. Additionally, a reduced incidence of skin cancer and a decrease in the severity of drug-associated mucocutaneous side effects were reported with omega-3 supplementation.

## Current Evidence Summary
Evidence for acne vulgaris is insufficient to support omega-3 fatty acids as a standalone therapy, though their anti-inflammatory properties warrant further investigation. Until more data is available, omega-3 supplementation should be approached as a potential adjunctive therapy rather than a primary treatment for dermatologic disorders.(no content)Lipid mediators derived from omega-3 fatty acids are anti-inflammatory molecules and play a major role in resolution of inflammation. Some studies have reported their effectiveness in resolution of eczematous lesions and prevention of allergic diseases.

Does It Work And Can It Reshape Your Jawline? - Family Dental Centre","url":"https://familydentalguelph.com/what-is-mewing-does-it-work-and-can-it-reshape-your-jawline/"},{"title":"Dr. Mike Mew & John Mew: Who Created Mewing and Orthotropics?","url":"https://www.mewing.app/blog/dr-mike-mew-john-mew"},{"title":"The Ultimate Guide to Mewing Benefits Techniques and Results - Grove Dental Clinic","url":"https://grovedentalclinic.com/the-ultimate-guide-to-mewing-benefits-techniques-and-results/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what research and professional sources say about mewing, orthotropics, and facial development:

## Overview of Mewing and Orthotropics

Mewing is an unproven form of oral posture training purported to improve jaw and facial structure. It was named after British orthodontist John Mew, who created the technique as a part of a practice called "orthotropics", and his son Mike. It involves placing one's tongue at the roof of the mouth and applying pressure, purportedly to modify the structure of the jaws.

## Scientific Evidence and Research Status

No credible scientific research has ever proven the efficacy of orthotropics, and most orthodontists do not view mewing as a viable alternative treatment to orthognathic surgery.(no content)There is no serious research that suggests mewing can change the shape of your jawline or help with other issues. Experts say it's unlikely you'll see any permanent change.(no content)Although Mew's theory does generate some plausible conclusions that can aid our profession in developing future surgical procedures, the public needs to be made aware that it is not based on sound scientific evidence that would make it a viable alternative treatment to orthognathic surgery.

## Theoretical Basis

The etiology of these malalignments have been items of controversy for many years, with some scientists claiming that they result from genetic influences and others claiming that they arise from the abnormal function of the tongue and jaw muscles. This latter concept is based on the hypothesis originally championed by Melvin Moss who postulated that facial bones develop in response to functional demands (functional matrix hypothesis).(no content)While there is some evidence supporting the principles of mewing, it is often based on small-scale studies or case reports. More large-scale, longitudinal research is needed to definitively prove its effectiveness.

## Professional Concerns

Mike Mew was expelled from the British Orthodontic Society and faced a misconduct hearing for posing harm to child patients who underwent his treatments. In 2024, Mew was struck from the dental register in the United Kingdom.(no content)The AAO does not recommend any attempts to move teeth or align jaws without appropriate supervision, as they likely won't achieve the results you're aiming for.

## Key Claims of Orthotropics

Orthotropics emphasizes the need to correct the patient's "jaw posture" by enhancing facial muscle tone, which in turn encourages "natural alignment of the teeth" and "positively affecting craniofacial structures." When resting, patients are instructed to seal their lips and press their tongue against the posterior hard palate as opposed to on the floor of the mouth.(no content)John and Michael Mew did not coin the term "mewing." The name stems from an online movement among people who wanted to change the appearance of their jawlines using ideas from orthotropics, which was originally intended for young children whose jaws are still growing. The North American Association of Facial Orthotics notes that orthotropics works best in kids aged 5-10.

In summary, while mewing has gained significant popularity on social media, the scientific and medical community emphasizes that there is currently no robust research supporting its effectiveness for facial restructuring, particularly in adults.

– PinkMirror Blog","url":"https://pinkmirror.com/blog/why-is-a-larger-ratio-of-interpupillary-width-to-bi-zygomatic-width-ratio-attractive-among-females/"},{"title":"New \"golden\" ratios for facial beauty - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19896961/"},{"title":"The ES Ratio [The Magnum Guide] – Magnum Workshop","url":"https://magnumworkshop.com/eye-separation-ratio/"},{"title":"Why is a small ratio of Interpupillary-Width to Bi-Zygomatic-Width Ratio attractive among males? – PinkMirror Blog","url":"https://pinkmirror.com/blog/why-is-a-small-ratio-of-interpupillary-width-to-bi-zygomatic-width-ratio-attractive-among-males/"},{"title":"New “golden” ratios for facial beauty - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0042698909005045"},{"title":"The interpupillary distance in adult Caucasian subjects, with reference to 'readymade' reading spectacle centration","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/224965158_The_interpupillary_distance_in_adult_Caucasian_subjects_with_reference_to_'readymade'_reading_spectacle_centration"},{"title":"Eye Spacing & Attractiveness: What Science Says","url":"https://www.tiktok.com/@qovesstudio/video/7098514880923258113?lang=en"},{"title":"The Power of Eyes: Secrets to an Attractive Face","url":"https://www.toolify.ai/gpts/the-power-of-eyes-secrets-to-an-attractive-face-169833"},{"title":"Descriptive statistics of facial attractiveness with different eye spacing. | Download Scientific Diagram","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Descriptive-statistics-of-facial-attractiveness-with-different-eye-spacing_tbl3_371269556"}]

Here are the key research findings on interpupillary distance and facial attractiveness:

## Key Research Studies

### The "Golden Ratios" Study (Pallett et al., 2010)
In four experiments, researchers tested the existence of an ideal facial feature arrangement that could optimize attractiveness. Participants made paired comparisons of attractiveness between faces with identical facial features but different eye–mouth distances and different interocular distances. They found that individual attractiveness is optimized when the horizontal distance between the eyes is approximately 46% of the face's width.(no content)These "new" golden ratios match those of an average face.

### The Eye Separation (ES) Ratio
The ES ratio stands for the Eye Separation ratio. To calculate it, you divide your IPD (interpupillary distance) by your bizygomatic width (the widest part of the face). The ideal range for the ES ratio is 0.45-0.47.(no content)Researchers modified images to different proportions and studied how people reacted to determine which looked most attractive. The ideal eye separation ratio of attractive faces was about 0.46, within the normal range for the ES ratio.

### Gender Differences
A small ratio of Interpupillary-Width to Bi-zygomatic-Width is considered attractive for males, whereas a larger ratio is considered attractive for females.(no content)For attractive faces, this ratio is consistently higher than that of average faces across different racial groups. The study acknowledges differences in the perception of beauty among races but notes that wide-set eyes are universally considered more attractive within each racial context.

### Additional Findings
According to the study by Sforza et al. (2015), attractive young women and men had longer eye fissure lengths on both sides compared to individuals with average attractiveness. This increased length, along with a larger external orbital surface area, may create a more aesthetically pleasing and youthful appearance.(no content)It is considered aesthetically pleasing if the distance between the eyes is roughly equal or similar to the width of one eye. The same can be said for the intercanthal distance (distance between the inner corners of the eyes).(no content)Research has concluded that the main effect of eye spacing is significant, and the mean value of facial attractiveness varies from one eye spacing to another.
